This stunning example of a Jaguar MKII hails from Southern California.The car comes with a nice book of extensive records reflecting the the tens of thousands spent on the restoration.A small example of funds spent was $5000 on wood refinish and $6000 spent on leather seats,and on and on it goes with  thousands spent in shops in the LA and Long Beach area.The car has a beautiful run and drive with a working overdrive.The gauges all work as designed and are in good condition,Headliner and carpets still look new.The exhaust is a nice stainless steel in as new condition.The chrome is like new and void of  pitting or fading.The glass is flawless,window regulators work easily and smooth.The motor,transmission and rear end were all party to the restoration as was the entire suspension and perform beautifully.
Review the pictures posted on the slideshow presentation,what you see is what you get,a very straight and beautiful well documented MKII 3.8 sedan.
The car is located in our indoor showroom 25 miles east of downtown Nashville Tn.Independent inspections are welcomed and encouraged.

The black leather interior is in excellent shape and really makes this Kougar pop. This sterling 1969 Jaguar E-Type is a comprehensively restored example of the Series 2 fixed-head coupe version of Sir William Lyons' groundbreaking sports car. Unveiled at the March 1961 Geneva Auto Salon, the E-Type was a sensational follow-up to the racing-purposed D-Type that scored three consecutive wins in the grueling 24 Hours of Le Mans in 1955, '56 and '57. The E-Type's body styling clearly drew its inspiration from the D-Type, and it adapted its monocoque construction and front space frame that supported the DOHC inline-6 engine, independent front suspension and hinged front bodywork. It surpassed even the D-Type in its sophistication, replacing the racer's live rear axle with a brilliantly designed independent rear-suspension system with inboard Dunlop disc brakes. The E-Type's engine displacement grew from the original 3.8L to 4.2L in 1964, when it was coupled with an improved 4-speed synchromesh manual transmission. The Series 2 E-Type introduced in 1968 brought significant design changes, most notably the elimination of the Series I's headlight covers, an enlarged grille opening for improved cooling and new larger tail lights beneath a full wraparound rear bumper. American-market E-Types incorporated the 4.2L inline-6 engine with new ribbed cam covers, dual Stromberg carburetors and dual exhaust. This beautifully restored 1969 Jaguar E-Type Series 2 Fixed Head Coupe was with its previous owner's family for 47 years. It shows a believed-correct 57,000 original miles, with only 500 miles since the completion of the restoration. Its combination of red paint and redline tires on chromed wire wheels is very popular with enthusiasts, who will also appreciate its sharp black-leather interior incorporating Smiths gauges and a signature wood-rimmed aluminum steering wheel. Ready to enjoy on the open road, this fine Series 2 E-Type is generously equipped with power steering, power disc brakes, factory air conditioning, tinted glass and a Blaupunkt stereo with cassette player.

title: 1968 Jaguar MK 2 2.4 Ltr RHD, Overdrive, In Very Good Condition

description: Jaguar MK2 1968, 2.4 ltr RHD, overdrive, in very good condition

This Jaguar MK2 240 was new delivered on the 6th of june 1968 in Manchester. The Mark 2 has the original colour combination of beige paint with chrome wire wheels and a fabulous red leather interior with the wooden dashboard. The car has the original matching numbers 2483CC engine with the very popular overdrive option. The car has disc brakes all around. This very original Jaguar comes with a lot of documentation since 1969 and is in very good condition.

This 1970 Jaguar XKE SII 4.2 is finished in Silver with a Tobacco interior.
The Series II Jaguars benefitted from more user-friendly mechanical improvements such as improved cooling and bigger brakes, plus options like power steering and A/C became available.
The Jaguar XKE series II is powered by a 246hp inline 6 cylinder engine with a 3 speed automatic transmission.
This example is non numbers matching.

The early history of this car is not known, although it does retain an original blue California license plate. The car was purchased by its current owner about 5 years ago whom immediately set out to make this a very useable daily driver.
Originally Sable brown, this car was repainted its current color four years ago.
The current owner has done extensive service and enhancements to make the car a useable classic.
Most significant work completed by British car specialist Delong's Automotive in Cambell, CA in 2014.
This included:
- Clean, paint and install motor and transmission. Correct block with Triple SU carburetors.
- Mounted new brake master cylinder.
- Fit upgrade A/C
- Send out Fuel Tank for cleaning and lining.
- New fuel lines.
- Rebuild front brake calipers
- Install Stainless steel exhaust
Factory A/C upgraded by Retro Air.
Recent repairs performed by Emiles Sports Car Performance:
- Replace Cap and Rotor, Ignition Wires and Spark Plugs. Set Ignition timing and Tripple SU Carbs including Choke Linkages.
- Repair Engine Cooling Fan Switch
- Re-Charge A/C System
- Hi Speed Mount and Balance Tires Universal Sport 185HR15
- Torque Sump Bolts and Timing Cover Bolts
- New Fuel Gauge Sending Unit.
Over $44,014.00 in receipts spent on upgrades and service in the last 4 years.
Interior is redone and looks basically as new. Moto Lita Steering wheel. All gauges are in good working order.
A great looking E Type that is ready to be used and enjoyed. California titled and current registration.
